content: The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the act. The remedies in subsection (a) are exclusive for covered persons under this section. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the act. Covered persons have the same rights and limitations as individuals under section 552a of title 5, United States Code. The Attorney General may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" for civil remedies under the Judicial Redress Act of 2015, with the concurrence of other relevant Secretaries. The Attorney General, with the concurrence of relevant Secretaries, may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if they have an agreement with the US for privacy protections. The Attorney General may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has an agreement with the US for privacy protections or if the country has effectively shared information with the United States. The Attorney General may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has effectively shared information with the United States for preventing, investigating, detecting, or prosecuting criminal offenses and has appropriate privacy protections. The Attorney General can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if it is not complying with the agreement for sharing information on criminal offenses with appropriate privacy protections. The Attorney General can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if it fails to comply with the information-sharing agreement or hinders the transfer of information for reporting or preventing unlawful activity. The Attorney General can revoke a foreign country's designation as a "covered country" if it fails to comply with the agreement, no longer meets requirements, or impedes information transfer to the US by a private entity. The Attorney General determines if an agency is a "designated Federal agency or component." The Attorney General may designate agencies other than the Department of Justice with the concurrence of the relevant agency head. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over any claim arising under this section. The Attorney General designates agencies for information exchange with covered countries in the interest of law enforcement. Determinations made are published and not subject to review. The US District Court in DC has exclusive jurisdiction over claims under this section. Definitions in the Act include "agency" and "covered country." The term "agency" refers to its definition in section 552(f) of title 5, US Code. "Covered country" means a designated country or organization. A "covered person" is a non-individual citizen of a covered country. "Covered record" has the same meaning as a record under section 552a of title 5, US Code. The term "covered person" refers to a non-individual citizen of a covered country. A "covered record" for a covered person is a record as defined in section 552a of title 5, US Code, once transferred by a public authority or private entity within a covered country. The term "covered record" is transferred by a public authority or private entity within a covered country to a designated Federal agency for criminal investigation purposes. The designated Federal agency is defined as a component of an agency designated accordingly. The term "individual" is defined as per section 552a(a)(2) of title 5, US Code. This section does not waive any privilege or mandate disclosure. The Act designates agencies and individuals as per section 552a(a)(2) of title 5, US Code. It does not require disclosure of classified information and takes effect 90 days after enactment.
